questions.text: During the examination of a 71-year-old female, you notice d’Espine’s sign to be present. Which of the following is not right regarding the interpretation of this clinical finding?

choices.text: The sign is elicited at around the level of T5 vertebra
This may be caused due to tuberculosis or sarcoidosis
Presence of severe kyphosis is not relevant
This may be caused due to lymphoma or metastasis

questions.solution:
False positives of d'Espine's sign can occur in severe kyphosis. Hence it cannot be considered not relevant.

d'Espine's Sign:

  • Sign of posterior mediastinal mass. 
  • Auscultation on either side of the spine and over spinous process is made at the level of T5 Normally, the lateral sounds should be louder and more distinct. The central sound being louder and more intense is considered a positive d’Espine’s sign. This suggests  continuity between the mainstem bronchus and the vertebrae, which is due to mediastinal lymphadenopathy, causes of which include:
        • Malignancy
        • Lymphoma
        • Metastatic cancer
        • Tuberculosis
        • Sarcoidosis

The typical description is the presence of high pitched tubular breathing and whispering pectoriloquy over the thoracic spine below T3 in adults and T4 in children and infants.
In patients with d’Espine’s sign, percussion over the spinous process of T1-5 causes the appearance of red spots over them if there is bronchial lymphadenopathy. This is known as Cattaneo’s sign.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a child, you notice the following peculiar ocular finding. This is termed as:
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows the color of one iris differs from the other, i.e different colors of the two iris. This is called Heterochromia iridum

questions.text: On tapping a long saphenous varicose vein in the lower part, the impulse can be felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand. This is known as ______
questions.solution:
In the Schwartz test, on tapping a long saphenous varicose vein in the lower part, the impulse can be felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand. 

Perthe’s Test: The affected lower limb is wrapped in an elastic bandage, after ruling out arterial occlusive disease. The patient is then asked to walk around. Severe cramping pain arises if there is deep vein thrombosis. 

Modified Perthe’s Test: A tourniquet is tied around the upper part of the thigh to prevent reflux down the vein and the patient is asked to walk around. In the presence of normal communicating and deep veins, the varicose veins will shrink. If there is any block, the veins will get more distended. 

Morrisey’s cough impulse test: The limb is elevated to empty the varicose veins. Now it is put to bed and the patient is asked to cough forcibly. An expansile cough impulse is felt at the saphenous opening if the saphenofemoral valve is incompetent. Similarly, a Bruit may be heard on auscultation.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 16-year-old female, you notice the following peculiar abnormality of the iris. This is called as
questions.solution:
Normally the pupil is placed slightly nasal to the center. This image shows an abnormally eccentrically placed pupil. This is called corectopia.

Corectopia is usually benign, non-progressive, and doesn't require any treatment. Treatment is required if it is associated with symptoms such as iritis, visual loss, etc

Other options:

Option A: The absence of the tissue of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid is known as coloboma of the uveal tract. Coloboma of the iris alone is referred to as incomplete coloboma and is typically seen in the inferonasal quadrant. Coloboma is shown in the image below. 

Option B: The presence of more than one pupil is called polycoria which is shown in the image below 

Option D: The congenital absence of an iris is known as aniridia. Complete absence is referred to as true aniridia and in the presence of a peripheral rim of the iris, it is known as clinical aniridia. Aniridia is shown in the image below

questions.text: The test depicted in the image, where cheek is drawn laterally, is used in the assessment of a patient with:
questions.solution:
The image shows Cottle's test where cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly.
If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

Cottle test is done before selecting a patient for surgery for DNS.

If the obstruction is relieved after the test, it means the surgery will be useful and the patient is taken up for surgery.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic is admitted to the ICU for treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia. Which of the following clinical examination findings is not likely to be associated with right lower lobe pneumonia?

choices.text: Dull note on percussion over the consolidation
Absent breath sounds over the consolidation
Increased vocal resonance over the consolidation

questions.solution:
Tubular Breath sounds are heard over the region of consolidation.

The following findings are seen in a consolidation:

  • Dull Percussion note
  • Tubular Breath sounds
  • Increased Vocal resonance
  • No Mediastinal shift
  • Added sounds- Midline Dull  Indux fine crackles or Redux coarse crackles

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following nail finding. Which of the following conditions would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows leukonychia totalis. Leukonychia is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states. 

Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discoloration of the nail.

It is seen in the following conditions:-

  • Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency
  • Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine
  • Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiformae, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE
  • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure.
  • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride).
  • Idiopathic

Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed - leukonychia striata/Aldrich–Mees lines.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, who is a known case of PVD, comes with complaints of rest pain. Which of the following values of ankle and brachial pressure correspond to the values that can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
An ABPI of <0.5 is associated with rest pain. The ABPI of 0.4, seen in case of option D, Ankle - 48/36mm Hg, Brachial - 120/80mm Hg, will be corresponding to that of rest pain.

ABPI = Systolic Pressure at Ankle/ Systolic Pressure in the arm(Brachial)

=48/120 = 0.4

 

Other options:

A - ABPI =1.25

B - ABPI = 1

C - ABPI = 0.75

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 48-year-old female who had undergone hysterectomy one year back, you notice the vault protrudes through the introitus. You would classify the vault prolapse as?
questions.solution:
Since the vault protrudes through the introitus, it is a second-degree vault prolapse.

Vault prolapse:

  • Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of both abdominal and vaginal hysterectomy when the supporting structures at the level I become weak and deficient.
  • It also results from failure to identify and repair an enterocele during a hysterectomy.
  • A technical error in the previous surgery, age, estrogen deficiency in a menopausal woman, parity, obesity, and chronic cough may contribute to its occurrence.

Management of Vault prolapse:

  • Right Transvaginal sacrospinous colpopexy is now considered the preferred surgery of choice in most cases.

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: You notice your senior resident performing the following test in a patient with an acute painful knee. Identify the test.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the anterior drawer test. This is done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

The patient is made to lie supine on the examining table. The hip is flexed to 45° and the knee is flexed to 90° with the foot flat on the examination table. The upper end of the tibia is held in both hands and is gently pulled anteriorly. Increased displacement compared to the normal knee indicates injury to the ACL.

Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. Here the leg is in slight external rotation and the knee is in a mid-flexed to 20° position. One hand is placed to stabilize the femur, while another hand applies the anterior force to the proximal tibia, as shown below.

Apley's grinding test and McMurray's test are done to detect meniscal injuries.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 54-year-old female patient with non-productive cough, exertional dyspnoea, and fatigue, you notice cyanosis and clubbing. On further examination, you hear late inspiratory velcro crackles at lung bases that are unaltered by coughing and the pulmonary function test showed a restrictive deficit. Which of the following conditions should this typical clinical picture prompt you to suspect?
questions.solution:
Interstitial lung disease (ILD) should be suspected in this patient.

ILD or diffuse parenchymal lung disease  is a heterogeneous collection of disorders that share a common presentation (dyspnea), physical findings (late inspiratory crackles), and chest radiographs (septal thickening and reticulonodular changes)

ILD occurs in patients aged more than 60 years and is common in women. They may present with an insidious onset of progressive dyspnea and non-productive cough. Late inspiratory velcro crackles on the lung base are one of the physical findings present in ILD. Cyanosis and clubbing are seen in advanced diseases.

In ILD, Pulmonary function test show a restrictive deficit. 

Based on the histopathological pattern on lung biopsy-

 Type of ILD Histologic pattern seen
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia A fibrotic or cellular pattern of non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis associated lung disease
Systematic sclerosis-associated ILD Both UIP and NSIP
 Sarcoidosis Non caseating granuloma

Other options:

Bronchiolitis, bronchiectasis, and bronchial asthma are obstructive lung diseases. Pulmonary function test show obstructive pattern. 

Note: Velcro crackles may also be heard in case of radiation pneumonitis. Also, it may be difficult to reliably distinguish the same from crackles of pulmonary edema. 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female has come for her annual well-woman checkup. During the breast examination, the following finding is noted. Which of the following is true regarding this finding?

choices.text: It is usually seen in benign inflammatory breast conditions
It is due to blockage of subcuticular lymphatics
It is due to Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast

questions.solution:
The image shows the Peau d'Orange appearance, a classical sign of breast carcinoma. It is due to the blockage of subcuticular lymphatics. The resultant edema deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles giving rise to the typical orange peel appearance. 

Other options:-

  • It is not necessarily always associated with nipple retraction, as seen in the image above where there is peau de orange, but no nipple retraction.
  • Peau d'Orange appearance is a classical sign of breast carcinoma not a finding of benign inflammatory breast condition.
  • Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast is called Mondor’s disease. The pathognomic feature of Mondor's Disease is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord, attached to the skin.

questions.text: Gentle pressure over the lateral lobes of the thyroid producing stridor is seen in
questions.solution:
Applying gentle pressure over the lateral lobes of the thyroid producing stridor is known as Kocher’s Test

Kocher’s Test: Done when one suspects pressure on the trachea. Gentle pressure on the lateral lobes of the thyroid causes stridor due to a narrow trachea. This test is positive in Multinodular Goitre and carcinoma infiltrating into the trachea. 

The Kocher eponyms:-

  1. Kocher’s thyroid dissector - used during a thyroidectomy to dissect the upper pole of the thyroid.
  2. Kocher’s transverse collar incision is centrally placed 4-6 cm transverse incision 1 cm below the cricoid cartilage parallel to the normal skin lines of the neck.
  3. Kocher incision - a subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology. Commonly used in open cholecystectomy.
  4. The Kocher Criteria for Septic Arthritis distinguishes septic arthritis from transient synovitis in a child with an inflamed hip.
  5. The posterior approach used in the operative management of acetabular fractures is known as the Kocher-Langenbeck approach.
  6. Kocher’s technique for reduction of shoulder dislocation - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation)
  7. Kocher’s hemostatic forceps has opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades. Used to hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles, Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel.


Note: Not all Kocher refers to the same person

Other options:

Pemberton's sign: The patient is asked to raise the hands above the head such that the arms touch the ears. This results in the engorgement of neck veins. It is seen in obstruction to major veins of the thorax.

Lahey's Method: Examiner stands in front of the patient and the lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the right lobe medially by the left hand and the left lobe is palpated with the right hand of the examiner. 

Callaway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side, in case of shoulder dislocation.

questions.text:
Match the following

Column A

  1. Image A
  2. Image B
  3. Image C
  4. Image D

 

Column B

  1. Beau's Lines
  2. Leukonychia Totalis
  3. Terry's Nails
  4. Lindsay's Nails
  5. Aldrich Mee's Lines
questions.solution:
• Image A - 3. Terry's Nails
  • Image B - 1. Beau's Lines
  • Image C - 5. Aldrich Mee's Lines
  • Image D - 4. Lindsay's Nails

 

Terry's nails are a type of apparent leukonychia of nearly the entire nail, obliteration of the lunula, and a narrow band of normal, pink nail bed at the distal border.

Beau’s lines are transverse grooves which are present on the nail and may be full or partial thickness through the nail. Transverse grooves may occur due to trauma, inflammation or neurological event, reflecting an acute systemic event (like MI, measles, mumps or pneumonia)

Mees' lines or Aldrich–Mees' lines, also called leukonychia striata, are white lines of discoloration across the nails of the fingers and toes (leukonychia). Mees' lines appear after an episode of poisoning with arsenic, thallium, or other heavy metals, and can also appear if the subject is suffering from renal failure.

 

Lindsay's nails, also known as Half and half nails show the proximal portion of the nail white and the distal half red, pink, or brown, with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. It is a rare but special clinical finding seen in chronic renal failure with a prevalence of 15-50%. It can also be seen in yellow nail syndrome, Crohn's disease, Kawasaki's disease, Behcet's disease, cirrhosis, hyperthyroidism, zinc deficiency, citrullinemia, pellagra, HIV infection, and even in healthy persons.

questions.solution:
Gutzmann’s pressure test is done in a case of puberphonia.

Pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and low tone voice can be produced. This is known as the Gutzmann’s pressure test.

Puberphonia:

  • Condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males.
  • They continue to speak in the pre-pubertal high-pitched voice.
  • The treatment is speech therapy

questions.text:
Match the following signs with the correct clinical description

Column A

1. Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity.

2. Bluish hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall

3. Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks

4. Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state.

 

 

Column B

A. Jacquiemer's Sign

B. Goodell Sign

C. Osiander Sign

D. Palmer's Sign

E. Piskacek’s Sign
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1. Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity - C. Osiander Sign

2. Bluish hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall - A. Jacquiemer's Sign

3. Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks - D. Palmer's Sign

4. Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state - B. Goodell Sign

 

E. Piskacek’s Sign - Asymmetric growth occurs to the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice that the jugular venous pressure (JVP) does not fall during inspiration and in fact, shows a paradoxical rise. Which of the following clinical conditions is least likely to be associated with the clinical finding seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration is known as Kussmaul's sign. It is not seen in Dilated Cardiomyopathy. 

Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure, the JVP falls. When there is an impairment in the filling or expansion of the right ventricle or a raise in the right atrial pressure, the blood backs up in the jugular veins. The backpressure causes an elevation or a failure in the appropriate fall in JVP during inspiration. It is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

It is also a common, isolated finding in patients after cardiac surgery without other hemodynamic abnormalities.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 33-year-old male who is being assessed for peripheral vascular disease, a Fuchsig’s test is performed. Which of the following is true about this test?

choices.text: It tests for the tibial artery blood flow.
The patient sits cross-legged with the limb being assessed below the other limb.
Rhythmic oscillations of the leg indicate significant stenosis
Patient’s attention is diverted in the form of taking history

questions.solution:
The patient’s attention is diverted in the form of taking a history.

Fuchsig’s Test:
It is performed to detect popliteal pulsation. The patient is asked to sit cross-legged with the leg being examined resting above the other limb - such that the popliteal fossa of the leg being examined rests on the knee of the other limb as indicated in the image.

The crossed leg will show oscillatory movements of the foot which occur synchronously with the popliteal pulse and the oscillations will be absent if the popliteal artery is blocked.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to the OPD by her mother as she noticed some deformity in the hip and lower limbs of the child. On examination,  asymmetry of groin crease is seen and the following test in the image is positive. What is the name of the test being performed?
questions.solution:
Galeazzi's test is shown in the above image.

It is done in children with unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) between 3 to 8 months of age.

The child is placed supine with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both the knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen to be at a lower level indicating femoral shortening. This is also known as Alli's sign.

Tests for DDH are:

  • Barlow's test
  • Ortolani's test
  • Galeazzi's test
  • Asymmetric skin fold test

Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In this test, direct median nerve compression elicits paresthesias and pain.

questions.text: Which of the following auscultatory findings do you expect to hear in a child during clinical examination in a child with an ASD?
questions.solution:
In Atrial septal defect (ASD), the characteristic finding is that the second heart sound is widely split and fixed during all phases of respiration.

Other options:

  • In Ventricular septal defect (VSD) – Wide variable splitting of the 2nd heart sound which is masked by the pansystolic murmur.
  • In Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) – the first sound is accentuated and the second sound is narrowly or paradoxically split.
  • In the Coarctation of the aorta – the first sound is accentuated, the second sound is normally split with a loud aortic component.

questions.text: On clinical examination, you find sensory loss in the region indicated. You would expect a deficit in:

choices.text: No associated motor weakness will be present

questions.solution:
The image shows Regimental Badge Sign. It is seen in Axillary nerve injuries. Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid which is responsible for abduction 15-90 degrees.

Other options:

  • Initiation of Abduction is not affected as it is caused by supraspinatus.
  • Overhead abduction is the function of serratus anterior and trapezius muscles and hence is not affected.
  • The posterior branch of axillary nerve supplies, teres minor and posterior of deltoid and terminates as the cutaneous nerve of armwhich supplies the skin over the lower half of deltoid. Deltoid muscle palsy can lead to loss of rounded contour of shoulder and palsy of lateral cutaneous nerve of arm are other significant features.

questions.text:
During the clinical examination of the cardiovascular system of a patient, you hear a Pan systolic Murmur. Which of the following conditions can it be?
  1. Aortic Stenosis
  2. VSD
  3. HOCM
  4. MR
  5. AR
questions.solution:
Pansystolic Murmurs can result due to 

  • Mitral regurgitation (MR)
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Tricuspid regurgitation (TR)

 

Aortic Stenosis (AS) and Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardio Myopathy (HOCM) would result in Mid-systolic Murmurs/Ejection Systolic Murmurs

 

AR would result in Early Diastolic Murmur

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is diagnosed to be sputum smear-positive for Tuberculosis. Based on further examination, a diagnosis of Right-sided tubercular pleural effusion is made. Which of the following clinical examination findings is not consistent with a diagnosis of right-sided pleural effusion?

choices.text: Stony dull percussion note on the right side
Mediastinal shift to the right side
Tracheal deviation to the left side
Increased vocal resonance above the level of effusion

questions.solution:
A mediastinal shift to the left side is expected in the case of a right-sided pleural effusion. 

Clinical findings in pleural effusion:

  • A mediastinal shift to the opposite side
  • Stony dull percussion note over the region of effusion
  • Diminished or absent breath sounds (tubular above level of effusion)
  • Reduced or absent vocal resonance (increased above level effusion)
  • Pleural rub may be heard above the level of effusion
  • Tracheal deviation to the opposite side in case of large effusions

A similar set of findings is seen in the case of empyema as well.

The tracheal shift to the same side in the presence of pleural effusion can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Mesothelioma
  • Empyema or effusion following pre-existing fibrosis
  • Mass with collapse and pleural effusion.

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs are correctly matched with regards to methylene blue - 3 swab test observation and its interpretation?
  1. The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - Ureterovaginal fistula
  2. The uppermost swab gets stained - Vesicovaginal fistula
  3. Middle swab gets stained -  Vesicovaginal fistula
  4. The lowermost swab gets stained - Urethrovaginal fistula
  5. Swabs don't take up the stain but get soaked with urine - Vesicovaginal fistula
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained -  Vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained - Urethrovaginal fistula

The 3-swab test is done to identify the type of genitourinary fistula. In this test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra, and 50-100ml methylene blue is injected. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula

The below image shows the 3-swab test.

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor

  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

questions.solution: In 3rd degree prolapse, the cervix lies outside the introitus.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of an elderly male patient with bilateral pitting pedal edema, a 3.7 cm rise of jugulovenous pulse is noted on gentle compression with the palm over the abdomen for about 30 seconds. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called positive hepatojugular reflux.

It is elicited by applying firm pressure over the liver for 15 to 30 seconds while observing the neck veins for increasing jugular venous pressure (JVP). This reflux indicates that the right ventricle cannot accommodate the increase in venous pressure.  

This sign is positive in right heart failure and severe tricuspid regurgitation. Additionally, there are prominent V waves and Y descent in tricuspid regurgitation.

JVP is measured as the distance between the top of jugular venous pulsation and the sternal angle of Louis. The normal height of JVP is between 6 cm to 8 cm H2O. 

Other options:

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the respective uses of Leopold First maneuver, Leopold second maneuver, Leopold third maneuver, and Leopold fourth maneuver in the corresponding order
  1. Determine the degree of descent
  2. Confirmation of fetal presentation
  3. Determine the fetal orientation
  4. Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is as follows

Leopold First maneuver - Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus

Leopold second maneuver - Determine the fetal orientation

Leopold third maneuver - Confirmation of fetal presentation

Leopold fourth maneuver - Determine the degree of descent

 

 

 

Leopold’s first maneuver (fundal grip): It is used to determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.

Leopold’s second maneuver (lateral grip): The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen and gentle deep pressure is exerted. The fetal back is felt as a hard-resistant structure and the fetal limbs are felt as multiple small irregular parts. It can be used to determine the fetal orientation based on whether the back is facing anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.

 

Leopold’s third maneuver (Pawlik’s grip) helps confirmation of fetal presentation. It involves grasping the lower part of the maternal abdomen with the thumb and fingers of one hand. The palpation of a hard and round mass indicates that the presenting part is the fetal head. A movable mass suggests that the presenting part is not engaged. If the presenting part is breech, it is felt as a large nodular mass.

Leopold’s fourth maneuver (pelvic grip): It helps determine the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for hearing loss. Rinne’s test shows that air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Weber's test lateralizes to the left ear. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the inference of the tuning fork tests is Weber's test lateralized to the left ear and Rinne's test normal. So the diagnosis is sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

 Weber test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worse ear
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear

Other options: 

Option A: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC) and Weber's test lateralized to the right ear. 

Option B: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC)and Weber's test is lateralized towards the left ear.

Option D: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear presents with a positive Rinne's test (AC>BC) and Weber's test is lateralized towards the right ear.

questions.text: A 34-year-old morbidly obese female patient was examined for thyroid swelling. The patient is asked to place the hands behind the neck and asked to push her head against the clasped hands on the occiput. This method is known as:
questions.solution:
In Pizzilo's method, the patient is asked to place their hands behind the neck and the patient is asked to push her head against the clasped hands on the occiput. It is used to inspect the thyroid gland more easily, especially useful in obese short-necked individuals. 

In Lahey's Method, the examiner stands in front of the patient and the lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the right lobe medially by the left hand, and the left lobe is palpated with the right hand of the examiner.

The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb. This gives a clear indication regarding the slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules. This is known as Crile’s method.

Kocher’s test is done when one suspects pressure on the trachea. Gentle pressure on the lateral lobes of the thyroid causes stridor due to a narrow trachea. This test is positive in multinodular goitre and carcinoma infiltrating into the trachea.

questions.text: A preterm baby is brought with symptoms of abdominal distention and hematochezia. The abdominal x-ray shows a portal vein gas shadow. The child's condition is classified as Modified Bell's stage IIIa, which of the following findings is likely to be seen?

choices.text: Modified Bell's Stage IIIa NEC has radiological findings only

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in the preterm baby is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). In a child with Modified Bell's Stage IIIA NEC, signs of generalized peritonitis like abdomen with guarding and rigidity would be present.

Necrotizing enterocolitis:

It is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated are:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is diagnostic. It corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures - nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

questions.text: A 55-year-old locomotive operator presents with complaints of worm-like swelling over his right leg. During clinical examination, a Brodie Trendelenburg test is performed. Which of the following statements is false regarding the test?

choices.text: A tourniquet can be used for occluding the saphenofemoral junction
Rapid filling  from above indicates saphenofemoral incompetence
Gradual filling  from below upwards indicates saphenopopliteal incompetence
Positive Brodie Trendelenburg test indicates a need for surgery

questions.solution:
The gradual filling of veins from below upwards indicates the perforator incompetence. Brodie Trendelenberg test is performed to test for the incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve and the communicating system.

1. Trendelenburg’s test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up:

  • Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence.
  • Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows the saphenofemoral incompetence.

2. Morrisey’s cough impulse: the patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates SFJ incompetence.

3. Schwartz test: If a thrill is felt at SFJ on tapping over the incompetent vein, indicates SFJ incompetence.

4. Modified Perthes test: A tourniquet is tied below SFJ and the patient is asked to walk. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT.

5. Fegan’s method - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence.

questions.text: The test performed in the following video is
questions.solution:
The test performed in the given video is Allen's test.

Allen's test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

Procedure:

  • The radial and ulnar arteries are occluded as the patient makes a tight fist so as to exsanguinate the palm.
  • Then the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation:

  • As occlusion of the ulnar artery is released, the color of the open palm is observed. Normally, the color will return to the palm within 5 – 6 seconds.
  • If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow.
  • The modified Allen’s test considers a threshold of 5 to 15 seconds.

Clinical significance:

  • In recent years, studies have shown that, although the Allen test is often used to identify patients at increased risk for ischemic complications from radial artery cannulation, the predictive value of this test is poor.
  • It is also used for identifying patients acceptable for radial artery harvest or use for coronary angiography.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following nail finding. Which of the following conditions is it likely to be associated with?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows subungual splinter hemorrhages, which are associated with infective endocarditis.

Subungual splinter hemorrhages are identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed. They are one of the vascular manifestations seen in infective endocarditis. They occur due to septic emboli breaking off from the valvular vegetation and blocking the peripheral capillaries.

Other peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous nodules that occur due to dermal infarcts due to septic emboli. They are usually found in the distal part of the fingers and are transient, as shown in the image below.

 

  • Janeway lesions are painless erythematous lesions in the palms, as shown in the image below.
  • Roth spots are retinal hemorrhages with a whitish center.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is denoted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given test is Adson’s test done for evaluation of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Thoracic outlet syndrome is a syndrome occurring due to neurovascular bundle compression in the thoracic outlet. Its causes include: 

  • Cervical rib
  • Anomalous insertion of the scalene muscles
  • Tumors in the neck region
  • Brachial plexus trauma and diseases. 

The image below shows the cervical rib. 

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A genital examination is being performed on a patient with perineal laceration post-vaginal delivery. The tear extends into the fascia and the musculature of the perineal body but the anal sphincter muscles remain intact.  Which of the following grades of perineal laceration does this correspond to?
questions.solution:
As the tear extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body and the anal sphincter muscles remain intact indicates this is a second-degree perineal tear.

The perineal tear is more common in primigravida and results from over-stretching or sudden stretching of the perineum during childbirth. Trauma to the perineum can also result in perineal tears.

Clinical features include the inability to hold the flatus and feces. Soreness over the peri-anal region can be seen due to constant irritation by stool. Palpation reveals the decreased/absence of a sphincteric grip depending on the degree of tear.

All recent tears should be repaired immediately. If there is a delay of 24 hours, the repair has to be withheld and the patient has to be started on antibiotics to prevent infection. Complete perineal tears that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery. In 3 months of time, any local infection that might have been present would subside, and the general condition of the patient will also improve. However, if the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms making the surgery difficult.

questions.solution:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 33-year-old female with endometriosis, which of the following clinical findings do you least expect to encounter?

choices.text: Cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments on posterior fornix examination
Freely mobile painless Nodular mass on abdominal examination
Bluish puckered spots over posterior fornix on speculum examination
Lateral forniceal tenderness in vaginal examination

questions.solution:
Abdominal examination in endometriosis would typically reveal a fixed, tender, cystic swelling, not a freely mobile painless Nodular mass.

 

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: An AV fistula in the forearm is created in a patient with end-stage renal disease so that he can undergo dialysis. Which of the following responses will you not see when you apply pressure proximal to the AV fistula?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure returns to normal when pressure is applied to an artery proximal to an AV fistula.

In an AV fistula, peripheral resistance is decreased because of which diastolic pressure is less leading to higher pulse pressure. Compression of the artery proximal to the AV fistula increases peripheral resistance leading to increased diastolic pressure and the pulse pressure returns to normal.

Compression of the artery proximal to an arteriovenous fistula results in:

  • Reflex bradycardia
  • Pulse pressure returns to normal
  • Decrease in size of swelling
  • Bruit will decrease or disappear

The reflex bradycardia and increase in blood pressure that immediately follows the sudden occlusion of an arteriovenous (A-V) fistula is known as the Nicoladoni-Branham sign.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient with Hodgkin’s lymphoma is noted to have Pel Ebstein fever. Which of the following is an accurate description of the fever pattern expected in this patient?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal without touching the baseline and the fluctuation does not exceed 0.6°C
Fever lasting 3–10 days is followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days
Temperature fluctuation exceeds 0.6°C , but without touching the baseline.
Fever lasts for 2–3 days followed by a remission lasting for 2 days and the fever reappears and continues for 2–3 days

questions.solution:
Fever lasting 3–10 days is followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days is known as Pel Ebstein fever.

 

Continuous Fever 

The temperature remains elevated above normal without touching the baseline and the fluctuation does not exceed 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in the cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc.

In Remittent Fever, temperature fluctuations exceed 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline.

Relapsing Fever is characterized by several days of fever followed by several days of afebrile period and then the cycle repeats., e.g. Borrelia infection, rat bite fever.

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third day, e.g. Plasmodium vivax, ovale, falciparum.

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth day, e.g. Plasmodium malariae.

In Saddleback fever, which is seen in Dengue,  initially, fever lasts for 2–3 days followed by a remission lasting for 2 days and the fever reappears and continues for 2–3 days.

In the case of Cyclic neutropenia, Cyclic neutropenia accompanied by fever occurs every 21 days.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false with respect to Apical Impulse/Point of Maximal Impulse (PMI)
  1. Apical Impulse not being visualized during Inspection can be considered normal
  2. Presence of the Apical Impulse medial to the midclavicular line or below the sixth intercostal space suggests left ventricular enlargement
  3. If the PMI is greater than 2.5 cm in size, left ventricular hypertrophy  is likely
  4. The apical impulse is seen at the right lower sternal border in case of situs inversus
  5. Left Ventricular Hypertrophy due to increased afterload results in sustained apical impulse
questions.solution:
1. Apical Impulse not being visualized during Inspection can be considered normal - True

The apical impulse/apex beat/ Point of Maximal Impulse (PMI) is normally visible in the vicinity of the fifth intercostal space. Apical Impulse not being visualized during Inspection is considered normal. It can be seen better in forced expiration or in the left lateral decubitus position.

 

2. Presence of the Apical Impulse medial to the midclavicular line or below the sixth intercostal space suggests left ventricular enlargement - False

Presence of the Apical Impulse lateral to the midclavicular line or below the sixth intercostal space suggests left ventricular enlargement

 

3. If the PMI is greater than 2.5 cm in size, left ventricular hypertrophy is likely - True

Normal apical impulse is described to be the size of a penny(~2cm). Increase in the size of the apical impulse to more than that is usually seen in left ventricular hypertrophy

 

4. The apical impulse is seen at the right lower sternal border in case of situs inversus - True

The apical impulse is seen at the right lower sternal border in the case of situs inversus and dextrocardia. Situs inversus can be differentiated from dextrocardia in the clinical examination by percussing to locate the gastric bubble.

 

5. Left Ventricular Hypertrophy due to increased afterload results in sustained Apical impulse - True

The apical impulse is considered sustained if P2 is coincident with or later than the palpable apical impulse. This is usually seen in case of left ventricular hypertrophy due to an increased afterload.

questions.text: A child was brought to the orthopaedic OPD for evaluation of the given knee deformity. What is it known as?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees physiological outward deviation (valgum). Any increase or decrease in angle can result in knee deformities. 

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at the knee joint with backwards bending.

questions.text: During the examination of an alcohol-intoxicated person, the pupils are constricted, but pinching the skin of the neck leads to transient dilatation of pupils, with a slow return to the original constricted state. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called McEwan's sign. In an alcohol-intoxicated patient, the pupils are constricted. But on the application of painful stimuli like pinching or slapping, the pupils slowly dilate. Once the painful stimulus is stopped, the pupils return back to their constricted state.

This is a characteristic finding of ethanol toxicity, seen at blood alcohol concentration levels >300 mg%. It is helpful in differentiating alcoholic coma from other comatose conditions.

The effects of alcohol intoxication at various blood alcohol concentrations are listed below.

Blood alcohol concentration (mg/dL) Effects 
30–50 Impairment of driving and similar skills
50–100 Reduced inhibitions, talkativeness, laughter
100–150 Incoordination, unsteadiness, slurred speech
150–200 Obvious drunkenness, nausea, and ataxia
200–300 Vomiting, stupor
300–350 Stupor , coma, risk of aspirating vomitus
350–450 and above Danger of death from respiratory paralysis

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness of both hands. He was asked to perform the test demonstrated below. What is this test?
questions.solution:
The test performed in the image is Roos test. It is also referred to as the elevated arm stress test (EAST). It is a provocative test for the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.

For this test, the patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby has come for a well-baby check-up. Which of the following should ideally be used for measuring the height/length of the baby?
questions.solution:
Recumbent length, measured using an infantometer is used to measure the length of the child as the age is only 18 months.

Ideally, for a child aged less than 2 years, the recumbent length is measured using an infantometer, while for a child older than 2 years standing height is measured using a stadiometer. 

In general, standing height is about 0.7 cm less than the recumbent length.

questions.text: A 14-year-old professional sports player presents with complaints of pain in the upper limb on lifting weights. During the clinical examination of this patient,  you ask to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Now, wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle. Which of the following conditions should you suspect?
questions.solution:
The Cozen's test has been performed and produces pain over the lateral epicondyle which is positive in tennis elbow - lateral epicondylitis.

Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) is tendinopathy characterized by pain arising from the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) at the lateral epicondyle. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at the origin during activities that involve repeated forceful wrist extension and supination (Eg: backhand in tennis and use of a screwdriver). 

Patients present with outer elbow pain, radiating down the forearm and along with morning stiffness of the elbow. The pain is often aggravated by lifting objects and shaking hands. The elbow may appear normal or have slight swelling, with a full range of movement.

Tenderness is present over the lateral epicondyle. Clinical tests for tennis elbow are:

  • Cozen's test: Resisted extension of the wrist with the elbow in full extension elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley’s test: extension of the middle finger against resistance elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mill's sign: Extension of the elbow in pronation with a flexed wrist elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: A consultant asked a junior resident to assess the ease of endotracheal intubation in a patient to be operated. The findings were similar to the schematic image given below. The resident should grade the oral opening as Mallampati class ___________
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, the base of the uvula, and the hard palate are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class III.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. In addition to classes I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and the tongue is protruded.

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of a difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of the inability to extend the fingers of his right hand. On examination, the patient was able to extend his right elbow and right wrist, but there was a loss of sensation in the area of the hand as shown in the image below. Where could be the possible site of injury?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical presentation, the site of injury is the lateral epicondyle.

  • The inability to extend fingers with the ability to extend the wrist and elbow indicates injury to the nerve supplying the extensor digitorum and extensor digiti minimi, which is posterior interosseus nerve.
  • Loss of sensation of the skin over the dorsolateral aspect of the palm and the dorsal aspect of lateral 3 and ½ digits up to the terminal interphalangeal joint indicates injury to the superficial branch of the radial nerve.

Since both the superficial branch and deep branches of the radial nerve are involved, the likely site of injury would be lateral epicondyle.

Other options:

  • Injuries around the axilla and radial groove will cause an inability in elbow and wrist extension, and in injuries around the proximal part of the radius, superficial branch of the radial nerve will be spared.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false with respect to Genslen's test.
  1. It is a Provocation test for sacroiliac joint pathology
  2. The patient is put in a supine position for this test
  3. The Hip and the knee of the affected side are flexed so as to fix the pelvis
  4. The knee of the affected side is extended with the hip flexed to elicit pain
  5. The hip on the normal side is hyperextended over the edge of the table
questions.solution:
1. It is a Provocation test for sacroiliac joint pathology - True
  2. The patient is put in a supine position for this test - True
  3. The Hip and the knee of the affected side are flexed so as to fix the pelvis - True
  4. The knee of the affected side is extended with the hip flexed to elicit pain - False
  5. The hip on the normal side is hyperextended over the edge of the table - True

 

Genslen’s/ Gaenslen’s test:

It is a Provocative test for Sacroiliac joint pathology. The patient is placed in a supine position and the hip and knee of the affected side are flexed to fix the pelvis. The hip on the normal side is hyperextended over the edge of the table. This will create a rotational strain on the sacroiliac joint causing sharp pain.

 

 

 

Gillie’s Test:

The patient is placed in a prone position and the pelvis is stabilized with a hand on the normal sacroiliac joint. The thigh of the affected side is hyperextended passively with the other hand eliciting a sharp pain.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions can Faget's sign be seen?
  1. Dengue
  2. Typhoid
  3. Brucellosis
  4. Leptospirosis
  5. Malaria
questions.solution:
Relative bradycardia/Faget’s sign is seen when patients have a lower heart rate than might be expected for a given body temperature. It can be seen in all of the above-mentioned conditions (1,2,3,4,5).

The body temperature is often considered an independent determinant of heart rate. It is estimated that for every centigrade rise in temperature, the heart rate increases approximately by 10 bpm.

Infectious organisms causing relative bradycardia include: 

  • Salmonella typhi (typhoid/enteric fever)
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Brucella (brucellosis)
  • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
  • Leptospira interrogans (leptospirosis)
  • Legionella pneumophila
  • Rickettsia spp.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Plasmodium spp. (malaria)

Viruses/viral infections:

  • Yellow fever virus
  • Dengue virus
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers - Early in the course of Marburg and Ebola
  • Viral myocarditis

Noninfectious causes include:

  • Drug fever 
  • Beta-blocker use 
  • Central nervous system lesions
  • Malignant lymphoma
  • Factitious fever

questions.text: An elderly man presented with pain and inability to move his shoulder after a fall. On examination, loss of normal contour of the shoulder was noted. Which of the following tests cannot be used to diagnose the likely condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of anterior shoulder dislocation. It cannot be diagnosed with the help of Gerber's test. This test is used to diagnose impingement between the rotator cuff and the coracoid process. 

Four tests can be used to diagnose anterior dislocation of the shoulder:

  • Bryant's test
  • Dugas test
  • Hamilton ruler test 
  • Callaway test   

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

questions.text: An ENT resident is performing the following maneuver in a patient as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the same?

choices.text: It builds negative pressure in the nasopharynx

questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Valsalva manoeuvre and it builds up positive pressure in the nasopharynx and not negative pressure.

In this test, the patient is asked to close the mouth and nostrils and blow. This produces positive pressure within the nasopharynx which opens the patent eustachian tube and is confirmed by the tympanic membrane bulge via otoscopy.

It is used to assess the Eustachian tube patency and to auto-inflate the middle ear.

It is contraindicated in:

  • Atrophic tympanic membrane as it might get ruptured.
  • URTI as the infection can spread into the middle ear.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions would a tracheal shift to the same side be associated with pleural effusion?
  1. Simple pleural effusion
  2. Mesothelioma with pleural effusion
  3. Tubercular pleural effusion
  4. Effusion following pre-existing fibrosis
  5. Mass with collapse and pleural effusion.
questions.solution:
The tracheal shift to the same side in the presence of pleural effusion can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Mesothelioma with pleural effusion
  • Empyema or effusion following pre-existing fibrosis
  • Mass with collapse and pleural effusion.

 

The trachea is ‘pushed’ to the opposite side in conditions like

  • Tumour
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pneumothorax

The trachea is ‘pulled’ to the same side in conditions like

  • The collapse of a lung
  • Fibrosis

questions.text:
Assertion: Differential Cyanosis occurs in all the cases of PDA
Reason:  Differential cyanosis in PDA usually manifests as cyanosis of only the lower extremities

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Differential cyanosis can be seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) when there is a reversal of shunt.

Differential cyanosis is manifested as cyanosis of only the lower extremities while upper extremities (usually the right arm) are unaffected. It is a result of reduced arterial oxygen saturation in the distal aorta compared to that in the aorta proximal to the left subclavian artery.

 It is seen with:

  • right-to-left shunting across a ductus arteriosus in the presence of coarctation or an interrupted aortic arch
  • patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with severe pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH)

 

Image: Right to left shunting of blood flow through a PDA between the aortic arch and pulmonary artery.

 

So, The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
